crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_covalent_bonds.convert_types_to_labels(bondtype, data_file_path)[source]ÔÉÅ

Convert a numeric bondtype to a meaningful label that specifies which alphanumeric atom types make up this bond.

Parameters:

  • bondtype (int) ‚Äì Numeric bondtype to be assigned a label.

  • data_file_path (str) ‚Äì Path to the data file that contains properly labeled Bond Coeffs section.

Returns:

Both atom types participating in this bond are connected by a hyphen.

Return type:

label (str)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_covalent_bonds.get_data_section_start_end(filepath, section, empty_lines_per_section=2, header_type='starts with')[source]ÔÉÅ

Read the LAMMPS data file specified by the filepath and return the indices of the first and final lines of the section specified. Also return the index of the last line in the file.

Parameters:

  • filepath (string) ‚Äì Path to the LAMMPS data file.

  • section (string) ‚Äì This string must match exactly with the line that indicates the start of the desired section in the LAMMPS data file. ex. If the desired section is the ‚ÄòBond Coeffs‚Äô section, section must equal ‚ÄòBond Coeffs‚Äô.

  • empty_lines_per_section (int) ‚Äì The number of empty lines that are in each section of the file. Default is 2, consistent with LAMMPS data file format.

  • header_type (string) ‚Äì Indicates whether the section header contains the section string or starts with the section string. Options are ‚Äòstarts with‚Äô or ‚Äòcontains‚Äô. Default is ‚Äòstarts with‚Äô.

Returns:

The index of the first line in the requested section. end_ind (int): The index of the last line in the requested section. final_ind (int): The index of the last line in the file.

Return type:

start_ind (int)

Raises:

ValueError ‚Äì Invalid input for header type if header_type is not a recognized sring.

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_covalent_bonds.identify_broken_bonds(pre_data_file, post_data_file, psf_file)[source]ÔÉÅ

Identifies broken molecular bonds by comparing bond data before and after a simulation, and enriches the results with atom metadata from a PSF file.

This function reads bond information from two LAMMPS-style data files representing the system before and after a simulation (e.g., ionization or tensile testing). It identifies bonds that existed in the pre-simulation file but are missing in the post-simulation file, indicating they were broken. It then enriches this list with atom metadata from a PSF file for better interpretability.

Parameters:

  • pre_data_file (str) ‚Äì Path to the data file containing bond information before the simulation.

  • post_data_file (str) ‚Äì Path to the data file containing bond information after the simulation.

  • psf_file (str) ‚Äì Path to the PSF file containing atom metadata (e.g., segment names, residue IDs).

Returns:

A DataFrame containing information about the broken bonds, including:

  • BondID

  • BondType

  • AtomID1, AtomID2

  • Segment names and atom types for both atoms involved in each broken bond

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

Raises:

  • FileNotFoundError ‚Äì If any of the input files are not found.

  • ValueError ‚Äì If the expected sections are not found in the input files.

Example

>>> broken_bonds_df = identify_broken_bonds("ionized.data", "tensile_test.data", "ionized.psf")
>>> print(broken_bonds_df.head())
crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_covalent_bonds.plot_bonds_broken_single_simulation(df, title=None, data_file_path=None, stress_df=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Plot the cumulative number of bonds broken of each time as a function of frame for a single simulation.

Parameters:

  • df (DataFrame) ‚Äì A DataFrame where each column contains the cumulative number of bonds broken at each frame in the LAMMPS simulation. Output from bondbreak_data_to_df.

  • title (str, optional) ‚Äì The value as the title of the plot created by this function.

  • data_file_path (str, optional) ‚Äì Path to the data file that contains properly labeled Bond Coeffs section for use with nested convert_types_to_labels function. Specify if legend labels should be converted from ‚Äòtype int‚Äô to ‚Äòtype int: alphanumericatomtype1-alphanumericatomtype2‚Äô

  • stress_df (pandas.DataFrame) ‚Äì The dataframe output by the function crosslinked_mfp_analysis.crosslinked_mfp_analysis. stress_strain.read_stress_strain which is assumed to correspond to the same simulation as the bond breaking data.

Returns:

Plot of all bond types that were broken throughout the simulation as a function of frame.

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_covalent_bonds.process_broken_bonds(simulation_path)[source]ÔÉÅ

Processes files in a directory that match the pattern ‚Äòbb*.dat‚Äô and aggregates broken bond data into a single DataFrame.

This function searches the specified directory for files whose names start with ‚Äòbb‚Äô and end with ‚Äò.dat‚Äô. For each matching file, it reads the second column (index 1) of numerical data, assumed to represent the number of bond breaks, and adds it as a column to a cumulative DataFrame. The column name is derived from the unique bond type indicated in the filename.

Args: simulation_path (str): The path to the directory containing the ‚Äò.dat‚Äô files.

Returns: pandas.DataFrame: A DataFrame where each column corresponds to a bond type and contains the number of breaks from the respective file.

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_coordination_bonds.generate_combinations(input_list, min_length=2)[source]ÔÉÅ

Generate all possible combinations of elements in the input list.

This function generates a list of tuples containing every possible combination of lengths from 2 to N (where N is the length of the input list) for a given list of string elements.

Parameters:

  • input_list (list of str) ‚Äì A list of string elements.

  • min_length (int) ‚Äì The minimum length of a combination.

Returns:

A list of tuples, each containing a combination of elements from the input list.

Return type:

list of tuple

Example

>>> input_list = ["a", "b", "c", "d"]
>>> generate_combinations(input_list)
[('a', 'b'), ('a', 'c'), ('a', 'd'), ('b', 'c'), ('b', 'd'), ('c', 'd'),
 ('a', 'b', 'c'), ('a', 'b', 'd'), ('a', 'c', 'd'), ('b', 'c', 'd'),
 ('a', 'b', 'c', 'd')]
crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_coordination_bonds.get_characters_after_last_colon(input_string)[source]ÔÉÅ

Extract all characters after the last colon ‚Äò:‚Äô in the input string.

Parameters:

input_string (str) ‚Äì The input string containing one or more colons.

Returns:

A substring containing all characters after the last colon.

Return type:

str

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_coordination_bonds.ion_coordination(ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame, atom_types)[source]ÔÉÅ

Keep track of which surroundings stored in ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame indicate a protein-protein interaction between requested atom types in atom_types list facilitated by the ions.

Parameters:

  • ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame (list) ‚Äì Each list element is a dictionary with keys specifying each ion‚Äôs residue ID. Corresponding value is an atom selection from the universe with all atoms within the cutoff distance of the ion.

  • atom_types (list) ‚Äì A list of atom types in string format to look for around iron atoms.

Returns:

Each list element is a list of the keys found in the corresponding list element of

ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame where an ion is facilitating a protein-protein interaction.

Return type:

protein_protein_tracking (list)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_coordination_bonds.plot_heatmap(data_dict, title='Heatmap of Interaction Presence', time_series=None, xlabel='Frame')[source]ÔÉÅ

Generates a heatmap from a dictionary where each key corresponds to a list of 0‚Äôs and 1‚Äôs.

Parameters:

  • data_dict (dict) ‚Äì A dictionary where keys are row labels and values are lists of 0‚Äôs and 1‚Äôs.

  • title (string) ‚Äì Plot title. Default is ‚ÄòHeatmap of Interaction Presence‚Äô.

  • time_series (list like) ‚Äì A list or array that is the same length as the number of keys in data_dict. Default is None

  • xlabel (string) ‚Äì x-axis label. Default is ‚ÄòFrame‚Äô.

Returns:

Displays a heatmap plot.

Return type:

None

Example

data_dict = {

‚ÄòRow1‚Äô: [0, 1, 0, 1], ‚ÄòRow2‚Äô: [1, 0, 1, 0], ‚ÄòRow3‚Äô: [0, 0, 1, 1]

} plot_heatmap(data_dict)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_coordination_bonds.protein_protein_ion_coordination(ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame, non_protein=['CLA', 'FE3P', 'HT', 'OT'])[source]ÔÉÅ

Keep track of which surroundings stored in ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame indicate a protein-protein interaction facilitated by the ion.

Parameters:

  • ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame (list) ‚Äì Each list element is a dictionary with keys specifying each ion‚Äôs residue ID. Corresponding value is an atom selection from the universe with all atoms within the cutoff distance of the ion.

  • non_protein (list) ‚Äì A list of all of the atom types in this system that are not protein formatted as strings.

protein_protein_tracking (list)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_coordination_bonds.track_protein_protein_interactions_over_time(protein_protein_tracking, ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame, non_protein=['CLA', 'FE3P', 'HT', 'OT'])[source]ÔÉÅ

Track whether or not each interaction detected in protein_protein_tracking is present at each timestep. 0 means the interaction is not present at this timestep. 1 means it is.

Parameters:

  • protein_protein_tracking (list) ‚Äì Each list element is a list of the keys found in the corresponding list element of ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame where an ion is facilitating a protein-protein interaction. Same format as output by the functions protein_protein_ion_coordination and ion_coordination.

  • ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame (list) ‚Äì Each list element is a dictionary with keys specifying each ion‚Äôs residue ID. Corresponding value is an atom selection from the universe with all atoms within the cutoff distance of the ion.

  • non_protein (list) ‚Äì A list of all of the atom types in this system that are not protein formatted as strings.

Returns:

A dictionary where keys specify which interaction this is. Value is a list, where each

entry is a boolean indicating whether or not this interaction is present at this timestep.

Return type:

interaction_states (dictionary)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_coordination_bonds.track_specific_interactions_over_time(protein_protein_tracking, ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame, atom_types)[source]ÔÉÅ

Track whether or not each interaction detected in protein_protein_tracking is present at each timestep. 0 means the interaction is not present at this timestep. 1 means it is.

Parameters:

  • protein_protein_tracking (list) ‚Äì Each list element is a list of the keys found in the corresponding list element of ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame where an ion is facilitating a protein-protein interaction. Same format as output by the functions protein_protein_ion_coordination and ion_coordination.

  • ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame (list) ‚Äì Each list element is a dictionary with keys specifying each ion‚Äôs residue ID. Corresponding value is an atom selection from the universe with all atoms within the cutoff distance of the ion.

  • atom_types (list) ‚Äì A list of atom types in string format to look for around iron atoms.

Returns:

A dictionary where keys specify which interaction this is. Value is a list, where each

entry is a boolean indicating whether or not this interaction is present at this timestep.

Return type:

interaction_states (dictionary)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_surroundings.collect_ion_surroundings(universe, cutoff, ion_type='FE3P', verbose=True, step=100)[source]ÔÉÅ

Make a list of dictionaries to store the surroundings of each ion within the specified cutoff distance at each frame.

Parameters:

  • universe (MDAnalysis Universe) ‚Äì trajectory for this simulation.

  • cutoff (float) ‚Äì The cutoff distance to be used to make interaction lists with ions.

  • ion_type (string) ‚Äì The atom type as it appears in the psf file used to make the universe.

  • step (int) ‚Äì Number of frames to skip between analyzed frames in the trajectory.

Returns:

Each list element is a dictionary with keys specifying each ion‚Äôs

residue ID. Corresponding value is an atom selection from the universe with all atoms within the cutoff distance of the ion.

Return type:

ion_surrounding_atoms_each_frame (list)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_surroundings.count_atom_types_around_ion_over_time(ion_surroundings)[source]ÔÉÅ

Count how many times each atom type is within the cutoff distance of an ion at each frame.

Parameters:

ion_surroundings (dictionary) ‚Äì Each list element is a dictionary with keys specifying each ion‚Äôs residue ID. Corresponding value is an atom selection from the universe with all atoms within the cutoff distance of the ion. Same as output of collect_iron_surroundings.

Returns:

A dictionary where each key is an atom type, and the corresponding value for each

key is a count of the number of times this atom type is within the cutoff distance of an ion at each frame.

Return type:

types_dict (dictionary)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_surroundings.make_timeseries(durations, dumpfreqs)[source]ÔÉÅ

Make a numpy array that contains the time in femtoseconds corresponding to each frame in a simulation.

Parameters:

  • durations (list) ‚Äì Each entry is the total number of timesteps in a dcd file.

  • dumpfreqs (list) ‚Äì Each entry is the number of timesteps between each output frame.

Returns:

Each element in time represents the time in real units corresponding to each frame

in the trajectory.

Return type:

time (np.array)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_surroundings.plot_counts_of_atom_types_around_ion(types_dict, timeseries, title, normalize=False)[source]ÔÉÅ

Make a plot of the number of times each atom type is within the cutoff distance of an ion over time.

Parameters:

  • types_dict (dictionary) ‚Äì A dictionary where each key is an atom type, and the corresponding value for each key is a count of the number of times this atom type is within the cutoff distance of an ion at each frame. Same as the output of count_atom_types_around_ion_over_time.

  • timeseries (list like) ‚Äì The timeseries data corresponding to this simulation.

  • title (string) ‚Äì Suptitle to be displayed over the plot.

  • normalize (boolean) ‚Äì Indicates whether to normalize type counts by the number of total ions in the system.

Returns:

Nothing.

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_ion_surroundings.sort_and_plot_unique_surroundings(environments_over_time, cutoff, timeseries, title, step=100, max_entries=6)[source]ÔÉÅ

Make a plot counting the number of times each unique environment appears at each frame.

Parameters:

  • environments_over_time (dictionary) ‚Äì A dictionary where each key is unique to a configuration of atoms around an ion. Each value is a list where each element specifies the number of times that unique configuration of atoms appears around an ion in each frame. Same as the output from unique_surroundings_frequency.

  • cutoff (float) ‚Äì The cutoff distance used to get ion surroundings.

  • timeseries (list like) ‚Äì The timeseries data corresponding to this simulation.

  • title (string) ‚Äì Suptitle to be displayed over the plot.

  • step (int) ‚Äì Number of frames that were skipped between analyzed frames in the trajectory, when running the function collect_ion_surroundings.

  • max_entries (int) ‚Äì Specifies the maximum number of data series to be included in the plot.

Returns:

Nothing.

For each unique set of atom types surrounding a certain atom, make a list that specifies how many times that unique set appears at each frame in the simulation.

Parameters:

surroundings_each_frame (list) ‚Äì Each list element is a dictionary with keys specifying each ion‚Äôs residue ID. Corresponding value is an atom selection from the universe with all atoms within the cutoff distance of the ion. Has the same format as the output of collect_iron_surroundings.

Returns:

A dictionary where each key is unique to a configuration of atoms around

an ion. Each value is a list where each element specifies the number of times that unique configuration of atoms appears around an ion in each frame.

Return type:

environments_over_time (dictionary)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_og312_surroundings.collect_og312_surroundings(universe, cutoff, step=100, resname='DO2P', verbose=True)[source]ÔÉÅ

From a specified MDAnalysis universe, for each residue with residue name equal to the variable resname, get a list of the atoms that are within a cutoff distance of the ‚Äòtype OG312‚Äô atoms on its sidechain. Return a list that contains an element corresponding to each frame analyzed in the trajectory. Each list element is a dictionary with keys indicating the segid:resid combination for this residue. Those keys specify another dictionary with two keys: ‚ÄòAtom Selection‚Äô, which holds the atom selection for the ‚Äòtype OG312‚Äô atoms in this residue, and ‚ÄòSurroundings Selection‚Äô, which holds the atom selection for atoms within the cutoff distance of atoms in ‚ÄòAtom Selection‚Äô excluding ‚Äòtype CA‚Äô atoms.

Parameters:

  • universe (MDAnalysis Universe) ‚Äì trajectory for this simulation.

  • cutoff (float) ‚Äì The cutoff distance to be used to define nearby atoms.

  • step (int) ‚Äì Number of frames to skip between analyzed frames in the trajectory. Default is 100.

  • resname (string) ‚Äì String formatted residue name for the residue containing ‚ÄòOG312‚Äô atoms. Default is ‚ÄòDO2P‚Äô.

  • verbose (boolean) ‚Äì Specify whether print statements are output after each frame in the MDAnalysis object has been analyzed. Default is True.

Returns:

Each list element is a dictionary with keys indicating the segid:resid combination for this residue. Those keys specify another dictionary with two keys: ‚ÄòAtom Selection‚Äô, which holds the atom selection for the ‚Äòtype OG312‚Äô atoms in this residue, and ‚ÄòSurroundings Selection‚Äô, which holds the atom selection for atoms within the cutoff distance of atoms in ‚ÄòAtom Selection‚Äô excluding ‚Äòtype CA‚Äô atoms.

Return type:

og312_surrounding_atoms_each_frame (list)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_og312_surroundings.count_atom_types_around_og312_over_time(og312_surroundings, verbose=True)[source]ÔÉÅ

Count how many times each atom type is within the cutoff distance of an og312 atom at each frame.

Parameters:

  • og312_surroundings (list) ‚Äì Each list element is a dictionary with

  • segid (keys indicating the) ‚Äì resid combination for this residue. Those keys specify another dictionary with two keys: ‚ÄòAtom Selection‚Äô,

  • residue (which holds the atom selection for the 'type OG312' atoms in this)

  • Selection' (and 'Surroundings)

  • selection (which holds the atom)

  • atoms. (for atoms within the cutoff distance of atoms in 'Atom Selection' excluding 'type CA')

  • verbose (boolean) ‚Äì If verbose, print an updated message every time a frame is analyzed. Default is True.

Returns:

A dictionary where each key is an atom type, and the corresponding value for each

key is a count of the number of times this atom type is within the cutoff distance of an ion at each frame.

Return type:

types_dict (dictionary)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.analyze_og312_surroundings.unique_og312_surroundings_frequency(surroundings_each_frame, verbose=True)[source]ÔÉÅ

For each unique set of atom types surrounding a group of atoms, make a list that specifies how many times that unique set appears at each frame in the simulation.

Parameters:

  • surroundings_each_frame (list) ‚Äì Each list element is a dictionary with keys indicating the segid:resid combination for this residue. Those keys specify another dictionary with two keys: ‚ÄòAtom Selection‚Äô, which holds the atom selection for the ‚Äòtype OG312‚Äô atoms in this residue, and ‚ÄòSurroundings Selection‚Äô, which holds the atom selection for atoms within the cutoff distance of atoms in ‚ÄòAtom Selection‚Äô excluding ‚Äòtype CA‚Äô atoms. Same as output from collect_og312_surroundings.

  • verbose (boolean) ‚Äì Specify whether print statements are output after each list element in surroundings_each_frame has been analyzed. Default is True.

Returns:

A dictionary where each key is unique to a configuration of atoms around

an ion. Each value is a list where each element specifies the number of times that unique configuration of atoms appears around an ion in each frame.

Return type:

environments_over_time (dictionary)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.stress_strain.elastic_modulus(ss_df, lower_strain=0.01, upper_strain=0.03)[source]ÔÉÅ

Calculate the elastic modulus as specific

Take as input a DataFrame formatted by the function read_stress_strain. Calculate the elastic modulus by performing a linear regression on stress values that correspond to strains between lower_strain and upper_strain.

Parameters:

  • ss_df (Pandas DataFrame) ‚Äì A Pandas DataFrame with columns ‚ÄòStrain‚Äô,‚ÄôPxx (kPa)‚Äô,‚ÄôPyy (kPa)‚Äô, ‚ÄòPzz (kPa)‚Äô extracted from the file specified by file_path.

  • lower_strain (float) ‚Äì A value that specifies the lower bound for a point to fall within the linear elastic region.

  • upper_strain (float) ‚Äì A Value that specifies the upper bound for a point to fall within the linear elastic region.

Returns:

The elastic modulus in MPa.

Return type:

elastic_modulus (float)

crosslinked_mfp_analysis.stress_strain.read_stress_strain(file_path, window_size=1000)[source]ÔÉÅ

Read the output of the file stress_strain.txt into a Pandas DataFrame. Calculate the cumulative toughness in a new column.

Parameters:

  • file_path (string) ‚Äì Specify the path to the file stress_strain.txt.

  • window_size (int) ‚Äì Use this integer as a window size over which to average stress data.

Returns:

A Pandas DataFrame with columns ‚ÄòStrain‚Äô,

‚ÄôPxx (kPa)‚Äô,‚ÄôPyy (kPa)‚Äô, ‚ÄòPzz (kPa)‚Äô extracted from the file specified by file_path.

Return type:

ss_df (Pandas DataFrame)
